Literature Review: The archaeology of long-distance connections across the ancient Indian Ocean has seen significant advancements in recent years, particularly in the period from 500 BCE to 1000 CE. This era marks a pivotal time in the development of maritime networks that facilitated the exchange of goods, ideas, and cultures across vast distances. Recent studies have leveraged interdisciplinary approaches, combining archaeology with materials science, to uncover the complexities of these ancient networks. One of the key areas of focus has been the movement of cultural elements, such as beads and ceramics, which serve as tangible evidence of the extensive trade and interaction that characterized the Indian Ocean region. Beads, in particular, have been a subject of intense study due to their ubiquity and the insights they provide into trade routes and cultural exchanges. Research by Carter (2016) has highlighted the role of carnelian beads in linking South Asia with the broader Indian Ocean world, suggesting a sophisticated network of trade that extended from the Indus Valley to the Mediterranean. Similarly, the study of ceramics has provided valuable information on the technological and stylistic exchanges between different regions. Selvakumar (2018) has documented the presence of Rouletted Ware across the Indian Ocean, indicating a shared ceramic tradition that points to direct maritime connections between South Asia and Southeast Asia. The application of materials science techniques, such as petrographic analysis and X-ray fluorescence, has further enhanced our understanding of these artifacts, allowing researchers to trace their origins and the routes they traveled. These studies have not only refined our knowledge of ancient trade networks but have also challenged some of the traditional interpretations of Indian Ocean maritime relations. For instance, the discovery of Roman glass in South Indian sites, as reported by Dussubieux et al. (2010), has prompted a reevaluation of the extent and nature of Roman trade in the Indian Ocean. Similarly, the identification of East African pottery in South Asia by Hawkes et al. (2017) has shed light on the bidirectional nature of these maritime exchanges. The integration of epigraphic and numismatic evidence has also contributed to a more nuanced understanding of the political and economic contexts in which these exchanges took place. The work of Ray (2003) on the inscriptions and coins found along the Indian Ocean littoral has revealed the role of local polities in facilitating and regulating trade. Furthermore, the study of shipwrecks and port sites has provided direct evidence of the maritime technologies and infrastructure that supported long-distance trade. The excavation of the Belitung shipwreck by Flecker (2001) has offered unprecedented insights into the scale and organization of trade between the Abbasid Caliphate and Tang China. Similarly, the archaeological investigations at the port of Mantai in Sri Lanka by Carswell et al. (2013) have uncovered a wealth of material that attests to its role as a major hub in the Indian Ocean trade network. These recent developments in the archaeology of the ancient Indian Ocean have not only expanded the material database but have also opened up new avenues for research. The interdisciplinary approach, combining traditional archaeological methods with advanced scientific techniques, has proven to be particularly fruitful in uncovering the complexities of ancient maritime networks. As the field continues to evolve, it is likely that future research will further refine our understanding of the long-distance connections that shaped the ancient Indian Ocean world.
